NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR This was just posted by @theanonmessage, a twitter account affiliated with Anonymous’ Operation Ferguson, a member of which I interviewed last night. According to @theanonmessage, this recording contains audio excerpts from St. Louis County police dispatch over several hours on August 9, 2014, the day Michael Brown was shot and killed by a Ferguson police officer. The dispatcher starts talking about the Brown shooting around the 10-minute mark, while intermittently handling other calls. See below the recording for an updating list of interesting moments, with time stamps included. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR If you want to try to decipher the dispatch codes, here’s a dictionary for that. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR 9:35: “Ferguson is asking for assistance with crowd control . . .” NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR 10:58: “Now they have a large group gathering there, she doesn’t know any further. . .” NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR 11:20: “We just got another call stating it was an officer-involved shooting . . .” NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR 11:30: “Be advised, this information came from the news . . .” NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR 11:55: “We’re just getting information from the news and we just called Ferguson back again and they don’t know anything about it . . .” NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR 20:00: “. . .destruction of property . . .” NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR 21:55: “They are requesting more cars. Do you want me to send more of your cars?” NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR 43:55: “Attention all cars, be advised that in reference to the call 2947 Canfield Drive, we are switching over to the riot channel at this time . . .” NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Update, 4:40 p.m. ET: I tried to verify the dispatch recordings with St. Louis County Police but their media contact, Brian Shelman, did not answer the phone and his voicemail was full. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Update 2, 5:05 p.m. ET: Mashable is confirming that the St. Louis County Police Department is “aware of this and currently investigating.” NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Update 3, 6:05 p.m. ET: A twitter follower of mine points out that the dispatch recording probably comes from Broadcastify, a database of public safety radio audio streams that’s available to anyone who pays for a subscription.
